steps.title: Abdominal muscles
steps.content: Abdominal muscles If youâ€™re chatting with someone about fitness, â€œabsâ€ might be short for your abdominal muscles. These are the muscles around your stomach that help strengthen your core. [2] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your friend might ask you how your abs are feeling after an intense workout, or you might share your 6-pack progress on Instagram. â€œThat workout was super intense, my abs are still sore today! ğŸ˜®â€ğŸ’¨â€ â€œHereâ€™s my 6-month fitness update. steps.title: Anti-lock braking system
steps.content: Anti-lock braking system When ABS is used as an acronym, it usually stands for a vehicleâ€™s anti-lock braking system. This is a safety feature that prevents your wheels from locking up when you have to brake suddenly and hard. If you see the ABS light on your dashboard, that usually means the system is deactivated due to a malfunction. Take your car to a mechanic to get your ABS checked out. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Absolute value
steps.content: Absolute value In mathematics circles, â€œabsâ€ is short for the absolute value of a number. The absolute value is how far a given number is from 0, which is always a positive value. [4] X Research source Abs is often used as a code in statistics software that returns the absolute value of some number. [5] X Research source While coding, you might type â€œAbs(-12)â€ and get 12 as your answer.

steps.title: Absent or abstract
steps.content: Absent or abstract While â€œabsâ€ usually stands for â€œabsolutelyâ€ in texts and online, almost any word that starts with â€œAbsâ€ can be shortened this way. Just pay attention to the context of your conversation to figure out what â€œabsâ€ means, or directly ask for clarification if youâ€™re unsure! [6] X Research source

steps.title: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms.
steps.content: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms. Learn these popular slang terms to stay in the know and keep your texts looking like English instead of gibberish: ISK : A typo for IDK (â€œI donâ€™t knowâ€) or â€œI should knowâ€ IDM : â€œI donâ€™t mindâ€ MCM : â€œMan crush Mondayâ€ WCW : â€œWoman crush Wednesdayâ€ MBN : â€œMust be niceâ€ FFF : â€œFollow for followâ€ PMO : â€œPut me onâ€ (introduce to someone or something) OOMF : â€œOne of my followersâ€ or â€œone of my friendsâ€ OMW â€™â€™: â€œOn my wayâ€
